notesStmt.note: Edited by Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.

Dates given according to Lady-Day dating.

Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 29 THE Parliamentary Intelligencer, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence, with the Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Monday July 9. to Monday July 16. 1660.
From Paris, July 10.
div.p:
The 5 in≈øtant Madamoi≈øelle de Alencon and de Valois, returned hither from the Court, we hear that their Maje≈øties are expected to morrow at Amboy≈øe, and are to come two days after to Fontanebleau, there to remain until all things are ready for their reception, which will be one of the magnificent entries that ever was made to any King, as may be judged by the great and ≈øumptuous preparations that are a making on all ≈øides, wherein our Inhabitants doe bu≈øy them≈øelves with an incredible dilligence and care, that they might as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible have the honor to receive that wonder of Queens, who being the fir≈øt fruit of our Peace, we doubt not but that we ≈øhall injoy all the good and nece≈ø≈øary
effects of it for the happine≈øs and felicity of the people. In the mean time, as every one, by a commendable emulation, doth ≈øtrive to te≈øtifie his Zeal in ≈øo illu≈øtrious an occa≈øion, the 8 in≈øtant a running at the ring was performed at the Academy of Me≈ø≈øiers de Me≈ømon and de Coulon, by ≈øeveral Gentlemen, who being the gallante≈øt of this Kingdome and very well mounted, ≈øhewed their Dexterity therein for carrying of the Prize, which was a rich Diamond given by the Count de Rower a Gentleman of Piedmont; the which was done in the pre≈øence of a very noble company, who were afterwards entertained with a ≈øumptuous Collation. The Marquis of Con≈øtans, Nephew to the Baron of Batteville came to this City going for England, from his Catholick Maje≈øty, to complement the King of England about his happy re≈øtauration.

div.head: From Poitiers, July 3.
div.p: The Court is expected this night at Lu≈øignan, and to morrow in this Citty, where all is preparing for the reception of their Maje≈øties.

The Duke of Savoys forces lent to the Republick of Venice pa≈ø≈øing upon the Po through this State, the Duke of Sermone≈øa our Governor hath publi≈øhed a Proclamation, forbidding, under very great penalties, to give any a≈ø≈øi≈øtance or reliefe to ≈øuch ≈øoldiers as ≈øhall runn away from their colours. And untill the Expre≈øs doth returne which he hath ≈øent to Naples to ha≈øten the money he is to receive from thence, he hath delivered his orders for the E≈øtapes for part of the Forces of the Milanez that are to be ≈øhipped at Final and to pa≈ø≈øe into Spaine again≈øt the Portugall.

div.head: Old Aberdeen, July 2. 1660.
div.p:
A≈ø≈øoon as the good news came to us of his Maje≈øties re≈øtauration, the Ma≈øters and Members of the Kings Colledge in this Univer≈øity of Aberdeen, did te≈øtifie their joy by ≈øinging
of P≈øalms, ringing of Bells, Bonfires, and ≈øuch other jolli ‚Ä¢ ies as are u≈øual; but knowing that they were not only tyed to his Maje≈øty as their lawful Soveraign King, but al≈øo by a nearer relation, as being only Patron of that Hou≈øe, they thought it incumbent on them, to give a more full te≈øtimony of their real joy and prai≈øe to God for bringing home their Patron: and therefore did a ≈øecond time, being accompanied with the Provo≈øt, Bayliffs, and Councel of Aberdeen, Sheriff and Commi≈ø≈øar, with the Mini≈øters and Students, with many other Gentlemen, go to the great Church, which was of old the Cathedral of Aberdeen, and there reverently hear their own Mini≈øter Preach a learned Thank≈øgiving Sermon, with great contentment to all the hearers. After Sermon they all came by way of Proce≈ø≈øion from the Church to the Colledge, ≈øinging P≈øalms: Then one of the Profe≈ø≈øors of Divinity made an Oration in the common School. The Magi≈øtrates of Aberdeen, with all other per≈øons of quality, were ≈øet in the middle of the Court near to the Fountain, before a Theatre hung all about with the Hangings which King James the fourth be≈øtowed upon the Colledge, with other ornaments and Garlands, and Crowns of flowers of all ≈øorts; the Picture of the King was in the middle, and upon his left hand his Excellency General Monk, becau≈øe the ≈øpeakers had in their Orations ≈øomething to ≈øpeak as to them: the ≈øtairs about, the windows, and all the Court below, were ≈øo full of ≈øpectators, that I thought there had ≈øcarcely been ≈øo many people in the parts about us. Upon this Theatre were ≈øet all the Ma≈øters and Students in order in their Gowns. In the fir≈øt place the Principal prayed and prai≈øed God, and did ≈øhew the hearers, that there were five young men, Students, to ≈øpeak in that place one after another: which was accordingly done; and indeed they did it very gravely and reverently. The ≈øubject of their Oration was as followeth: The fir≈øt ≈øpoke of the great happine≈øs which Scotland enjoyed under Kings ≈øince the days of Fergus the fir≈øt, until the time of the late troubles. The ≈øecond ≈øpoke of the mi≈øeries the Nations ≈øuffered by the late Kings Murther, the pre≈øent Kings removal
from his ju≈øt Rights and Dignities. The third ≈øpoke of the prai≈øes due to his Excellency for re≈øtoring the King to his Kingdoms. The fourth ≈øpoke of the great happine≈ø≈øes, and many favours be≈øtowed upon the Univer≈øity by Kings, and of the lo≈ø≈øes ≈øu≈øtained by the interruption of Kingly Government. The fifth had a gratulatory Oration for the Kings return. After they had ended, there was a Latine Hymn of about eighty lines, very harmoniou≈øly and chearfully ≈øung, and at the end of every fourth line, Vivat Rex Carolus, vivat. It is incredible to know how joyful the people of all ranks were, who were pre≈øent: the people of this poor Town did te≈øtifie their un≈øpeakable joy all the night with Bonfires, ringing of Bells, playing on Mu≈øical In≈øtruments, and dancings, yet without the lea≈øt debauchery of drinking; ≈øuch an influence hath his Maje≈øties ≈øobriety upon the people. All things were ≈øo carried, as be≈øt ≈øhewed their real duty to his Maje≈øty, and good di≈øcipline of this place. Much of the honor of this (though all were active enough) is due to that truly learned Dr. More, Profe≈ø≈øor of Medicine here.

div.head: From Rochel, July 3.
div.p:
The 29 of the la≈øt month, the King with Cardinal Mazarine and ≈øome other Grandees, arived at Bourage, and the next day his Maje≈øty went to dinner in the Ca≈øtle of O
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on, and afterwards went to ≈øee the ≈øhips that were in the River of Sendre, and returned about night to Bourage.

We are much rejoyced here to under≈øtand of the good agreement between the King and Parliament, de≈øiring the continuance of Gods ble≈ø≈øing upon them; and to that purpo≈øe, his Electoral Highne≈øs hath appointed a day of thank≈øgiving to be kept through his whole land, July 3. and after the Sermons, here, and at Frankendal, and Cau ‚Ä¢ , all the c ‚Ä¢ nnon to be ≈øhot off, and all the citizens and ≈øoldiers to do the like with their muskets.

div.head: From the Hague, June 29.
div.p:
The Lord Frederick van Alefe ‚Ä¢ t of Se ‚Ä¢ guard, Coun≈øellor of State, and Deputy-governor of the Dukedoms of
Sle≈øwig and Hol≈øtein, to his Maje≈øty the King of Denmark, goeth in quality of Extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øador of the ≈øaid King, to congratulate his Maje≈øty of Great Britain, and is already on his way hither, intending to take ≈øhipping at the Brill or Flu≈øhing, as ≈øoon as wind or weather ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ll ≈øerve; ≈øo that you may expect him in England with ‚Ä¢ n few days.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter July 5.
div.p:
On Monday, Serjeant Tyrell
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to the Common Pleas Bar by Serjeant Glanvile and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Littleton; where being come, the Lord Chancello ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ the rea≈øons that induced his Sacred Maje≈øty to make ‚Ä¢ oi≈øe of him to be one of the Ju≈øtices of that Court; to which when Serjeant Tyrell made a mode≈øt reply, ≈øpeaking of his unfitne≈øs among≈øt ≈øo learned men to undertake ≈øo great a charge, &c. the Lord Chancellor cau≈øed the Patent to be read; after which the Serjeant being in Court, he fir≈øt took the oath of Supremacy and Allegiance, and then the oath as Ju≈øtice of that Court; which being ended, the Lord Chancellor went away, leaving the Serjeant to act in his place as one of the Ju≈øtices of the Common-Pleas.

On Tue≈øday, the Lord Chancellor ≈øitting in his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, Serjeant Turner came to the Bar of that Court. The Lord Chancellor laid down the rea≈øons why his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to call him to be Baron of his Court of Exchequer, in that he had been unbia≈ø≈øed and con≈øtant in his Judgment, and had acted nothing prejudicial to his Maje≈øty, or contrary to his tru≈øt, &c. After a reply in excu≈øe of him≈øelf, his Maje≈øties Parent to con≈øt ‚Ä¢ tute him one of the Barons of his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, was rea ‚Ä¢ , and being afterward ≈øworne in Court, he ≈øate as one of the Barons of the ≈øaid Court.

div.head: White ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll, July 7.
div.p: This day His Maje≈øty conferrell the place of Lord Almoner on that mo≈øt Pious and Reverend, Brian, Lord Bi≈øhop of Salisbury, who was his Maje≈øties ‚Ä¢ utor when he was Prince of Wales.

His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to re≈øtore that antient Honor of the Dominion and Government of the I≈øle of Man, to the
Right honorable Charles Earl of Derby, which hath been kept from that Noble Family ever ≈øince the murder of the Noble and valiant James Earl of Derby: A Family that for their loyalty and fidelity to the Crown have ≈øuffered as deep as any of his Maje≈øties Subjects of this Nation. Great care is al≈øo taken by the Earl of Derby for ≈øetling the Church-government both in Doctrine and Di≈øcipline, as it hath been formerly accu≈øtomed in that I≈øland.

Al≈øo William Lord Craven is made Governor of the ca≈øtle of Shrewsbury, in which County his Lord≈øhip hath ample Revenues, which till now without the lea≈øt pretence or colour of Ju≈øtice have been deteined from his Lord≈øhip, but now are re≈øtored to him with all Arrears; and his Lord≈øhips Deputy-Governor is Sir William Whitmore Baronet, a family that have ≈øuffered very much for their Loyalty and Allegiance.
The Lord Charls Howard, one of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt Honorable Privy Council, is al≈øo made Governor of Carli≈øle.
That Loyal Gentleman, ≈øir Richard Ba≈ø≈øet, is made Governor of Cardiff Ca≈øtle.
Sir Jordan Cro≈øland, who from the beginning of the≈øe Wars, did his Maje≈øty ≈øuch good ≈øervice in the North, is now made Governor of Scarborough Ca≈øtle.
Col. Tho. Blague, who ≈øo long kept the Ca≈øtle of Wallingford when Governor thereof (being one of the Grooms of his Maje≈øties Bed-chamber) is now made Governor of Yarmouth and Langher Point.
Captain William Lennard, a Gentleman of a Noble Family, and tryed courage, is made Governor of the Forts of Tilbury and Grave≈øend.
Cap. Increa≈øed Collins, having a former Patent from his late Maje≈øty, and continuing Loyal, is now confirmed by his Maje≈øty, Governor of Moats Bulwark.
Major Waterhou≈øe, a per≈øon of who≈øe courage and fidelity his Maje≈øty under≈øtands ≈øo much, is now Deputy-Governor of Garn≈øey.

Letters are lately ≈øent down to Scotland to Judg Mo≈øcley,
and the other Engli≈øh that were Commi≈ø≈øioned as Judges there, to forbear to act any further in their former capacity, and to repair into England.

And now (after all the≈øe Ca≈øtles and Commands be≈øtowed on per≈øons of Honor and Loyalty) be plea≈øed to take notice, That the Marquis of Argile, the Marquis o ‚Ä¢
A ‚Ä¢ trim, Sir Arthur He≈øilrig, and Sir Henry Vane are Arre≈øted of High Trea≈øon, and committed clo≈øe pri≈øoners to the Tower of London ‚ñ™ When Sergeant Ch ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ ock went to apprehend the Marquis of An ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ m, he was denied entrance; but the General beforehand having furni≈øhed him with three files of Mu≈øqueteers, he forced two dores, and found the Marquis ≈øitting on his bed ≈øide, 'twas about two of the clock la≈øt Sunday morning. The Sergeant civilly offered him to re≈øt there all night, where he would g ‚Ä¢ ve h ‚Ä¢ s attendance: The Marquis afterwards went to bed; but upon con≈øideration ro≈øe again, and was conveyed privatly to the Tower. The Marquis of Argyle was got through the Inner chamber and Pre≈øence, intending: as he ≈øaith) to have ≈øpoken with his Maje≈øty, but was ≈øoon ob≈øerved, and upon information, a Warrant was granted to apprehend him. In his pa≈ø≈øage through Cheep-≈øide, he de≈øired he might go and ≈øpeak with an Eminent Learned Mini≈øter at Ald ‚Ä¢ rmanb ‚Ä¢ ry Serjeant Charneck told him. That his Lord≈øhip might ≈øend for that, or any other Mini≈øter to the Tower, but at pre≈øent he could not permit him thither. We could tell you many ob≈øervable particulars of this Marquis, but at pre≈øent may it ≈øuffice to acquaint you, That this was the day whereon formerly his Lord≈øhip in a friendly manner had invited the Laird of Mac-Nachton, to his Hou≈øe to Dinner, and there ≈øeized upon him with much le≈øs civily then the Serjeant did his Lord≈øhip; but Mac-Nachton ≈øeeing him-life in danger, ≈øound means to e≈øcape, and is ≈øtill alive to receive the reward of his Loyalty and Valor, being the la≈øt Commander that bore Arms for the King in Scotland, and (in the judgement of all parties) a per≈øon of as high merit and excellent Conduct, as any Gentleman of that Nation.

We have not room to in≈øert more particulars of the two Knights, Sir Arthur and Sir Henry ‚ñ™ but mu≈øt conclude with a de≈øire, that you would con≈øider how of all per≈øons in England, Scotland and Ireland ‚ñ™ the≈øe 4 were the grand in≈øtruments of the fouer different Intere≈øte, and till now could never meet together.
There are other Pri≈øoners committed to the Black-Rod, who≈øe names with more particulars you may have in the next.

div.head: From Rome, June 14.
div.p:
Cardinal Carbarigo having received the Cardinals hat of the Pope in a publick Con≈øi≈øtory, hath been magnificent
‚Ä¢ y treated by the Cardinal Patrone, with the Cardinal Man
‚Ä¢ ni, Dom Mario and Dom Augu≈øtino. There have been great rejoycings at the Chri≈øtning of the young Prince Borgle≈øe, who≈øe Father kept that day an open table, and gave abundance of Almes. Cardinal Bandinelli is gone for his Legation of the Rom ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ e, and Mr de Bo ‚Ä¢ compagne, Archbi≈øhop of Bonoma, hath taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his place of Magiordome to the Pope, who ≈øeems to be willing to excommunicate the Vice Roy of Naples, becau≈øe of the impri≈øoning of Cardinal Filomarinis two Nephews, who have been ≈øent by him into Spain; but the bu≈øine≈øs begins to incline to ≈øome way of accommodation. We are yet uncertain whether Queen Chri≈øteana ≈øhall goe for Swedeland. We hear from Naples that great rejoycings were made there for the Peace between the Emperor and the Swedes, the Poles and the Elector of Brandenbu ‚Ä¢ g.
This day our Court is to remove from Front to go to the Ca≈øtle belonging to the Count Philip d' Aglie, and from thence to the plea≈øure hou≈øe of Madame Royall.

We have had here „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ n Earth quake, which extended it ≈øelfe to the very Pyr ‚Ä¢ nean Mountains, and overthrew many hou≈øes. We he ‚Ä¢ re that in Bearne it hath dryed up the Minerall Springs. We heare likewi≈øe that Belyer and the Seau ‚Ä¢ d Urgel, were delivered to the Spaniards the 22 in≈øtant, and Ro≈ø ‚Ä¢ t and Cap de Quires upon the 26. The Spaniards have put ≈øome additional men in Figuiers whereas the report goes they intend to build a Royall fore. Mon≈øieur d' Orvill, formerly Governour of Puycerda is likewi≈øe fortifying of Livia, which is one of the villages of Cerdagne remaining in the hands of the French.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p: ‚òû The Memoires of the Duke of Rohan: Or, a Faithful Relation of the mo≈øt remarkable Occurrences in France; e≈øpecially concerning, tho≈øe of the Reformed Churches there. From the death of Henry the Great until the Peace made with them in June, 1629. Together with divers Politick Di≈øcour≈øes upon ≈øeveral occa≈øions. Written originally in French, by the Duke of Rohan, and now Engli≈øhed by George Bridges of Lincolas-Inn E≈øq Sold by Gabriel Bedel and Thomas Collins at the Middle-Temple Gate in Fleet≈øtreet.

The Clerk of A≈ø≈øize, Judges Mar≈øhal, and Cryer; being the true manner and form of the proceedings at the A≈ø≈øizes and General Gaol-Delivery, both in the Crown Court, and Ni≈øi Prius Court, and the right ways of entering of all Pleas, Verdicts, Judgments, and Orders in either of the ≈øaid Courts. By T.W. And al≈øo the Law of Charitable U≈øes.
Both ≈øold by Timothy Twyford within Inner-Temple Gate.

A Brief View of the late Troubles and Confu≈øions in England, begun and occa≈øioned by a prevailing Faction in the Long-Parliament, from the year 1640. unto this pre≈øent year 1660. By William Yonger Gent.

Stem ‚Ä¢ na Sacrum. The Royal Progeny delineated, and with ≈øome Notes explained, ≈øhewing His Sacred Maje≈øties Royal and Lawful De≈øcent to His Crown and Kingdoms, from all the Kings that ever reigned in this Nation; with a Stem annexed, ≈øetting ≈øorth the Norman, the Saxon, the Briti≈øh, and the Scoti≈øh Line. By Giles Fleming Rector of Waddingworth, in the Dioce≈øs and County of Lincoln.
Both ≈øold by Robert Gibbs, at the Ball in Chancery-Lane.

The Pa≈øtor and the Clerk: Or, a Debate (Real) concerning Infant-Bapti≈øm, together with ≈øome Retractions of the Author, and Repentings, in reference to the late Civil and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Changes. By John Ellis.
A Dying Fathers Living Legacy, to his Loving Son. Both ≈øold by Eli≈øha Wallis at the Gilded-hor≈øe-≈øhooe in the Old-Bailey.

God ≈øave the King: A Sermon Preached at Lyme-Regis, at the Proclaiming of His mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Grace of God, of England, Scotland, France and Ireland King Defender o ‚Ä¢ the Faith, &c. By Ames Short, M. A. „Äà‚óä„Äâ there. Sold by William R ‚Ä¢ ybould at the Unico ‚Ä¢ n in St. Pauls Churchyard.

‚òû The Fourth Volumn of Clelia, that Excellent Romance. Written by Mon≈øieur d ‚Ä¢ Sc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ery. Sold by Humphr ‚Ä¢ y Mo≈øeley at the Princ ‚Ä¢ 's „Äà‚óä„Äâ in St. Pauls Church yard, and Tho. Dri ‚Ä¢ g at the George in Fleet≈øtreet, near St Dun≈øtans Church.

div.head: Hamburgh, July 10.
div.p: No news from Coppenhagen or Sealand, Field-Mar≈øhal Wrangle is arived at Stral≈øund again. He was going for Sweden, but an Expre≈øs met him at Sea w ‚Ä¢ th Orders out of Sweden, for his return. The Imperiali≈øts lie ≈øtill in their quarters, they have lately demanded quarters in the four Lands here of this Town. The Swedes mu≈øtered their forces the la≈øt week in the Dukedome of Breme, which were about 7 or 8000 men. There is a Report, as if they intend to go for Mun≈øter, the Town being ≈øaid to call them to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance: There is now open war between the Bi≈øhop and Town of Mun≈øter.
They write from Dantzick, that Czarneski hath beaten the Mu≈øcovites.

div.head: El≈øenor, 26 June.
div.p: The Head-quarter is removed from Roskield to this place, where all Generals and chief Officers of the Army are a≈ø≈øembled; they have received intimation from the Court of Sweden, what his Maje≈øty intends to do with this Army, viz. To disband a great part of them upon payment of their arrears. The Princes of Sultsback, Birchenfield, and Darm≈øtat, are this day gone for Sweden; but by the way between this and Hel≈øinbergh they were entertained by the Hollands Admiral de Ruyter in his ≈øhip, with great magnificence and ≈øhooting off his Canon. The Ratification of the peace was brought hither out of Sweden la≈øt Sunday night. Admiral de Ruyter will employ all his Ve≈ø≈øels to tran≈øport the ≈øoldiers, which now will be done very ≈øuddenly.

div.head: War≈øovia, July 3.
div.p:
Here is extraordinary great rejoycing over the Victory obtained again≈øt the Mo≈øcovites; ≈øome ≈øay there are 12000 of the Enemy killed upon the place. The chief General Kowansky
≈øaved him≈øelf with the flight only, with 100 hor≈øe, who is ≈øtrongly pur≈øued, and it is verily believed he will be overtaken. Another General of theirs Szerbati is taken Pri≈øoner, and General Junowa ≈ølaine. The ≈øaid Szerbati being brought in to our General Czarnecky, his pre≈øence ≈øaid, our Czar hath brought me into this ≈øad condition, who would not take our advice‚ñ™ and it is to be feared he ≈øeeks his own utter ruine. This Szerbati with many German Officers being taken pri≈øoners, are upon the way to be conveied hither with all the Colors taken, whereof the Szar his own color is blew, imbroidered with Gold and Pearls.

Ours have taken of the Enemy all their Baggage, Ammunition and 40 great pieces of Ordinance, be≈øides great ≈øtore of Provi≈øion which was di≈øtributed among the Souldiers. We hope by this Victory, the ≈øiege before Lackowiz which was begun by the Mu≈øcovites almo≈øt half a year agoe, will now be rai≈øed.

Out of Ukrania, they relate that our General Wihowsky ≈øhould have been beaten by the rebellious Co≈ø≈øaks, but of this there is no certainty as yet. His Maje≈øty intended to go for Dubno the 12 of this month, to be near to Lithuania and Ukrania.

div.head: From Stetin, July 8.
div.p: The Imperial Forces in Pomerania and Mechlenburg do ≈øtill lye in their old quarters, but are ready for a March upon the fir≈øt order they ≈øhall receive. They have already been Mu≈øtered, and got a months Pay be≈øides Cloathes.

div.head: Am≈øterdam, July 10.
div.p: At Utreckt, ≈øome differences are fallen out betwixt the Mini≈øters and the Magi≈øtrae about the di≈øpo≈øing of the Church lands; The Mini≈øters having the common People on their ≈øide, the Magi≈øtrate got privately ≈øome Souldiers into the Town for their protection, ≈øince which all is quiet again.

div.head: An Adverti≈øement of a Book newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p: ‚òû The World Surveyed: Or, the famous Voyages and Travels of Vincent le Blanc, or White of Mar≈øe ‚Ä¢ ll ‚Ä¢ s; who from the age of Fourteen years, to Three≈øcore and eighteen, Travelled through mo≈øt parts of the World. The whole work enriched with many Authentick Hi≈øtories. Originally written in French, and faithfully rendred into Engli≈øh by F. B. Gent. Sold by John Starkey at the Miter, near the Middle Temple Gate in Fleet≈øtreet.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: WHereas by Commi≈øsion from His mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty under His Great Seal of England, bearing date the Fifth of this in≈øtant July; as al≈øo by His Maje≈øties Letters Patents, dated the Eleventh following. Sir William Throckmorton was con≈øtituted and appointed Knight-Mar≈øhal of His Maje≈øties Hou≈øhold, and Court of Mar≈øhal≈øey: He the ≈øaid Sir William Throckmorton doth declare, That for the ea≈øe of His Maje≈øties Subjects in their due Proceedings in the ≈øaid Court of Ju≈øtice, that the Fees payable upon every Arre≈øt, ≈øhall be abated Two ≈øhillings and ≈øix pence; and that for the future preventing tho≈øe high Mi≈ødemeanors and Corruptions, which have been committed by ≈øeveral ≈øubordinate Officers, or Counterfeit-pretenders to that Court, to the great vexation and oppre≈øsion of His Maje≈øties good people.

That he the ≈øaid Knight-Mar≈øhal, as Judge in the ≈øaid Court, will frequently appear therein, to hear and receive all Grievances and Complaints that can be pre≈øented again≈øt any of the Officers or Counterfeits as afore≈øaid; and then and there to inflict mo≈øt exemplary puni≈øhment according to Law, upon all tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors or offenders what≈øoever.

MO≈øt excellent and approved Dentrifices to ≈øcour and clean≈øe the Teeth, making them white as Ivory, pre≈øerves from the Toothach; ≈øo that being con≈øtantly u≈øed, the parties u≈øing it, are never troubled with the Toothach: It fa≈øtens the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , ≈øweetens the Breath, and pre≈øerves the Gums and Mouth from Cankers and Impo≈øthumes, and being beaten to powder, and drunk in Wine, or any other drink, is a good remedy for any Flux or Lask. Invented and made by Robert Tur ‚Ä¢ er, the onely Au ‚Ä¢ hor of them, and are onely to be had at the Hou≈øe of Thomas Rockes, Stationer, at the Holy Lamb at the Ea≈øt-end of St. Pauls Church, near the School, in Sealed Papers.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p:
‚òû MASORAH, Critica Divina: A Synoptical Directory on the Sacred Scriptures, di≈øtributed into four Parts. 1. Of the Canons of Scripture, Old and New. 2. Of the Tran≈ølations of Scripture, Auogtophical and Apographical. 3. Of the Interpretations of Scripture, Literal and My≈øtical. 4. Of the Authorities of Scripture, Divine and Eccle≈øia≈øtical. The Fir≈øt Part Dedicated to his Maje≈øty, by Ferdinando Parkbur≈øt,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Printed by Tho. Newcomb.

Solomons ‚ñ™ ble≈ø≈øed Land, A Sermon upon Eccle≈ø. 10.17. Preached before an Extraordinary A≈ø≈øembly at Newark upon Trent, May 29 1660. Being the Birth-day of Our Soveraign Lord Charls the Second, King of England, &c. By Samuel Brun≈øel, Rector of Bingham in Nottingham≈øhire. Sold by Henry Seile over again≈øt St. Dun≈øtans Church in Fleet≈øtreet.

‚òû The Death of Charls the Fir≈øt lamented, with the Re≈øtauration of Charls the Second congratulated: Delivered in a Speech at Wellington, May 17. 1660. By William Langley ‚ñ™ Sold by Richard Lownds at the White-Lyon in St. Pauls Churchyard, and Simon Gape next to Hercules Pillars in Fleet≈øtreet.

div.head: An Adverti≈øement.
div.p: THe be≈øt and noble≈øt guilt Skins for Patens, for Creatio ‚Ä¢ s, Charters, for Corporations, Grand Commi≈ø≈øions, Commi≈ø≈øions to foraign Kingdoms, &c. And likewi≈øe the be≈øt and noble≈øt skins in black and white for all manner of other Patents, Pardons, and Royal Grants, to be pa≈ø≈øed under His Maje≈øties great Seal; and al≈øo for Recoveries, and other Exemplifications, are ≈øold by George Tomlyn in Leather-lane in Holborn, Henry Twyford in the Middle‚ñ™ Temple, and John Bellinger in Cliffords-Inn Lane in Fleet≈øtreet.

div.head: An Adverti≈øement to all Sheriffs, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Attor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es, Sollicitors, Clerks, Serjeants, Bailiffs, &c.
div.p: ALl ≈øorts of Blank Bonds, with Conditions for payment of money at a place certain, and without; Counterbonds for money, and Bonds for performance of Covenants, for Arbitraments with Umpire and without Umpire; for Appearances in any Court of Record, Counterbonds upon the ≈øame, Replevins, and Bonds upon Replevins, Bailiffs Bonds to the Sheriffs for their true performance of their Offices, Bills of Sale, Bonds of Redemption, General Relea≈øes, Licences for Ale-hou≈øes. All ≈øorts of Sheriffs Warrants upon mean Proces, County Court Warrants, &c. Warrants for Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Indentures of Apprentice≈øhip. And al≈øo the be≈øt and faire≈øt pieces of Text, and ≈ølouriing for Letters Patents, Fines‚ñ™ Recoveries, and o ‚Ä¢ her Exemplifications. Are to be ≈øold by John Bellinger in Cliffords-Inne-lane Fleet≈øtreet, London.

And by him is al≈øo to be ≈øold, That mo≈øt incomparable piece of Court hand, which (of it ≈øelf alone, without other Ma≈øter) is compleatly fitted to teach ‚Ä¢ ll Clerks, and others, perfectly and exactly to write the ≈øame hand, and to read ancient Records, and abreviate words.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p: The Guards at la≈øt are di≈øcharged from their attendance on the two Hou≈øes of Parliament; who being now upon the performance of their duty to his Maje≈øty, as Loyal Subjects, and the true ≈øervice of their Country in their Repre≈øentatives, need no other ≈øecurity, then the hearts and affections of the people.

div.head: Whitehal.
div.p: The Regiment that was lately Col. Streaters is now conferred upon the Right Honorable John Lord Bela≈øis, who by his wounds and impri≈øonments hath ≈øufficiently te≈øtified his Honor and Loyalty to His Maje≈øty.
His Lieutenant Colonel is that gallant Gentleman, Colonel Anthony Gilby.
His Major is Col. John Streater, who ≈øo re≈øolutely attempted the Pa≈øs near Daventry, when Col. Lambert was taken.
Lieut. Col. George Welden and Robert Smith, are two of his Captains.

Col. Charles Fairfax, though very aged, was never known to do any thing unbefitting a Soldier; and for his eminent ≈øervice in the late happy Change, and particularly at Hull, hath not onely a continuance of his Regiment, but for ever an 100 l. per annum out of the Cu≈øtoms of Hull.
Col. Edward Harloe, Elde≈øt Son of Sir Robert Harloe, is now Colonel of a Regiment of Foot, Captain of Hor≈øe, and Governor of Dunkirk.
His Brother Major Robert Harloe, is now Colonel of a Regiment of Hor≈øe in Dunkirk, a per≈øon who≈øe abilities are not unknown as a Member of Parliament, or of the Army.
Major Tobias Bridges hath well merited to continue ≈øtill Major of the ≈øame Regiment.
By the next you will have a particular account of the Regiment of his Highne≈øs the Duke of York.

On Monday, July 16. His Maje≈øty and His two Royal Brothers, with divers Lords and Per≈øonages of Honor were entertaind by Sir William Waele at his hou≈øe in Throckmotton-≈øtreet. This is that Sir William Wale that entertained his Grace the Duke of Albemarlie, when it was agreed the Secluded Members ≈øhould be admitted to re≈øit; for which, and other late ≈øervices, he hath obtained to be Purveyor of His Maje≈øties Wines.

If the City knew her own happine≈øs, they may now ≈øee the difference betwixt the pre≈øence of a King, and the tyranny of an U≈øurper, where the known Laws and the e≈øtabli≈øhed Religion, are not cau≈øes of Plunder and Impri≈øonment, and there is no ≈øtrife betwixt the City and the Country, but who ≈øhall ≈øhew mo≈øt duty to the King.

We have not told you of any places of Civil Juri≈ødiction conferred by his Maje≈øtie upon any of his good Subjects, contenting our ≈øelves to let you know how the Militia and Army Offices have been di≈øpo≈øed, as the thing of more pre≈øent con≈øideration and nece≈ø≈øity; however we dare promi≈øe you when the Li≈øt and Settlement of the Army is all fini≈øhed to give you upon occa≈øion an account how Officers in his Maje≈øties Hou≈øhold, in Courts of Judicature, as well as in other places are fill'd and ≈øupply'd.

WHereas in ≈øome Prints there is mention made of the manner of the Reception of Mon≈øieur Pelnitz, and particularly, that he was conducted to audience in his Maje≈øties own Coach; we mu≈øt inform the Reader, That it was not his Maje≈øties Coach, but the Coach of the Earl of Manche≈øter, Lord Chamberlain of his Maje≈øties Hou≈øhold.
On Wedne≈øday the 18 in≈øtant, the Earl of St. Albans went to Grave≈øend, and ≈øo forward on his Voyage towards France. What is the cau≈øe and purport of his journey, we need not tell you.

His Maje≈øty notwith≈øtanding all di≈øcouragements by the „Äà‚óä„Äâ
weather, and the multitude of ≈øick and infirm people, abated not one of his accu≈øtomed number, but touched full Two hundred that had the Evil; an high Conviction of all ≈øuch Phy≈øitians, Chirurgions, or Apothecaries, that pretend ≈øelf-pre≈øervation, when the langui≈øhing Patient requires their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

More pri≈øoners are committed to the Black Rod, particularly _____
Acton (his Chri≈øtendom we know not) who is notorious enough by the name of Acton, Po≈øt-ma≈øter of Ba≈øing≈øtoke; with whom al≈øo are Capt. John Griffith and Capt. Edward Alcock, who, we may ≈øafely ≈øwear, are unknown to us by their virtues.

Major Waring is committed thither al≈øo. This is the Son of the old Ca≈øh-keeper Waring, and Brother-in-law to Major Salway. This Major Waring will finde better u≈øage at the Black-Rod, then he gave to the Gentlemen of Shrop≈øhire, where he was Oliver Cromwel's Triennial Sheriff (Pardon us for calling him Sheriff, who rather was the Jaylor of that County) and was the be≈øt Repre≈øentative of the Committee of Safety, who≈øe Confident he was.
The la≈øt of the pri≈øoners is Col. Henry Brad≈øhaw, elde≈øt brother to that Mon≈øter John Brad≈øhaw, whom we ≈øcorn to honor ≈øo much as to rail at, if it were manners to rail at the Devil.

And while we mention the name of Brad≈øhaw, we can tell you, That His Maje≈øty hath given leave unto Henry Williams alias Cromwel of Ram≈øey, in the County of Huntingdon E≈øq to leave out the Alias Cromwel.

It is therefore de≈øired, you would take notice, That this Mr. Henry Williams is Grandchild to Sir Oliver Williams, and ≈øon to Col. Williams a Commander in His late Maje≈øties Army, to whom, onely with his family, this favor is granted; and (to deal clearly) in tho≈øe black days of the Protectordom, this Gentleman was not onely civil to all, but made it his endeavor to a≈ø≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and relieve all hone≈øt and loyal per≈øons. It is his due, and it were be≈øt to deny it.
London, Printed by J: Macock, and Tho. Newcomb, 1660.
